title: 115_hr2046
content: The "Peer-Support Specialist Act of 2017" may be cited as the short title. The Act includes a report on best practices for peer-support specialist programs, training, and certification. The "Peer-Support Specialist Act of 2017" requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to submit a report on best practices and standards for establishing and operating health care programs using peer-support specialists within 2 years of the Act's enactment. Peer-support specialists are defined as individuals who use their personal recovery experience from mental illness or substance use disorder to provide support to others. The "Peer-Support Specialist Act of 2017" defines peer-support specialists as individuals who use their personal recovery experience to provide non-medical services within their scope of practice. They may facilitate support groups, work one-on-one with individuals with mental illness or substance use disorder, and meet criteria specified by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The report under the "Peer-Support Specialist Act of 2017" includes information on best practices and standards for defining peer-support specialists, such as formal work experience, types of specialists used, required exams, code of ethics, and additional training in areas like ethics, crisis intervention, and confidentiality laws. The curr_chunk discusses requirements for completing documentation activities and necessary skill sets for peer-support specialists, including knowledge of risk indicators, de-escalation techniques, suicide prevention, trauma response, stages of change, and accessing mental health services. Requirements for continuing education include effectively working in care teams, facilitating service coordination, and supporting individuals in achieving recovery goals. The Peer Professional Workforce Development Grant Program is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary of Health and Human Services awards grants to develop and sustain behavioral health paraprofessional training programs to increase the number of trained peers, recovery coaches, and addiction specialists. Eligible entities include community colleges and training programs. The Secretary of Health and Human Services awards grants to develop and sustain behavioral health paraprofessional training programs. Special consideration may be given to programs targeting peer professionals serving youth ages 16 to 25. $100,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2018 to 2022.
